Case.Petitioner: Commissioner of Central Excise, Goa and Another
Case.Bench: S. H. Kapadia AND Aftab Alam

JudgmentText.P: The Judgment was delivered by : HON'BLE JUSTICE S. H. KAPADIA

1. This batch of civil appeals is filed by the Department against the decision of CESTAT dated 23.1.04 in Final Order Nos. 103 to 105 of 2004. These are virtually cross appeals to civil appeals filed by the assessee bearing Civil Appeal Nos.4309-4311 of 2008 - M/s. Pleasantime Products & Anr. v. Commissioner of Central Excise, Mumbai-I, in which we have delivered the judgment today. The question in both sets of civil appeals, however, is common as far as the game "Scrabble/Upwords" is concerned.
2. In this batch of civil appeals filed by the Department we are concerned with classification of 12 items falling within the declaration filed by M/s. Funskool (India) Ltd.
3. We make it clear that the following three items are classifiable under Heading 95.04 of the
(iii) Scrabble/Upwords (in terms of our judgment delivered today in M/s. Pleasantime Products (supra))

B.P: In our judgment in M/s. Pleasantime Products (supra), we have broadly indicated the tests to distinguish toys, puzzles and games in the context of Chapter 95 of the CETA. The tests applied by the Department, namely, age of the player, is not correct as indicated in our judgment in M/s. Pleasantime Products (supra). Therefore, we remit this case to the Tribunal for de novo consideration in accordance with law. It is made clear that the Tribunal will decide the controversy only with regard to nine out of 12 items. We once again declare that "Scrabble/Upwords" is a game falling under Heading 95.04 of CETA.

JudgmentText.P: 5. Accordingly, civil appeals filed by the Department are allowed with no order as to costs.

EditorsNote.P: Excise - Central Excise Tariff Act, 1985, heading 95.04 - Classification - Games - Scrabble/Upwords - Snake and Ladder, Monopoly and Scrabble/Upwords - Whether impugned products are classifiable under heading 95.04 of Tariff? - Held, as per SC judgment in M/s. Pleasantime Products and Another v. CCE, Mumbai-I 2009 ILO SC 1526, the tests to distinguish toys, puzzles and games in the context of Chapter 95 of the CETA, 1985 have been indicated - Therefore, the impugned products fall under Heading 95.04 of CETA, 1985 - However, tests applied by the Department, namely, age of the player, is not correct as indicated in M/s. Pleasantime Products, therefore, the case is remitted to the Tribunal for de novo consideration in accordance with law, only with regard to nine out of 12 items - Revenue's appeal allowed.
